Very well, I'll return once I've scouted the village.
Nemám zájem.
Yes?
Kdo jsi?! Drž se ode mě dál!
Co se tu stalo?
Wildlings, {my lord/my lady}! They come during the night, put the village to the torch! Horrible, t'was!
My name is {playername}. I've been sent to scout out the village. Tell me where the wildlings went.

I don't know {my lord/my lady}, but they can't have gone far! Mayhaps they went for another of the villages, greedy savages that they are. Maybe Goodwife Myra over at Last Hearth have heard something, she's the biggest gossip in the realm. She works in the kitchens, along with that daughter of hers. My ma always told me kitchens are where all the important news comes through first. She should have known, worked in one for a while.
Jak to že jsi přežil útok divokých?

I hid in the top of that huge pine over there. Saw their savagery though! T'was horrible {my lord/my lady}, horrible. Goodwife Hanna must've been raped by half a hundred men, and her daughters where made to watch, before their turn came! They're beasts in human skin these wildlings. Sleep with giants, snarks and worse.
Jsi šílený?
Co chceš?
Have you heard of any wildlings being sighted?
Oh gods no! Haven't seen a wildling since I was but a wee child. Big shaggy man he was, put an axe in the blacksmiths skull.
Do you know of any who might have seen or heard anything?

Talk to my daughter Jess. Foolish girl, she been talking to all kind of travellers passing through. Been laying with a few of them as well, I should think, hah. Spreading her legs for any man who wants her, she'll have a swollen belly before the years out I tell you!
You've been most helpful.
Kdo jsi?
I'm Goodwife Myra, the oldest woman in this here castle! Been living here for decades, I have.
Zapomeň na to, odcházím.
What do you want, huh?
Careful, girl. Insolence is not a virtue.
Forgive me, {my lord/my lady}. I did not see clearly who spoke to me.
Your mother seemed to think that you may have heard about some wildlings.

Yes, {my lord/my lady}. They come over the Wall, Willam said, though Halbert said they sail across the Bay. Then again, what do they know. Josmond said he'd heard m'lords talk about wildlings in the Lonely Hills, close to that old abandoned holdfast. Now, {my lord/my lady}, I'm sure you can tell me much more about these wildlings than any of those boys. Mayhaps you could tell me about them in the back of the barn?
No. I don't lie with filthy peasants.
Might be I could.
Forgive me, {my lord/my lady}, is just that I saw your fancy clothing, thought you might fancy me!
Oh my! Come then, take me in the barn, {my lord/my lady}!
Nothing, I'm leaving.
When you're dead, you'll join us!
I don't intend to meet my end here.
I can't die! See, we're already dead! Dead, dead, dead!
What do you want? What do you want? I saw an elk carrying a dead man, in a dream!
I've come searching for wildlings. Have you seen them?

Saw a fist in the snow, the dead was crawling all over it! Saw a dark shape in the north! It speaks to me, whispers! Saw wild men too, but they're my brothers now! Beneath the ground we'll lie, but not yet! When the dawn is ended, I'll have my bride, my cold bride, in the snow and in the dirt!
Tell me where the wildlings went. Now.
Hah! Heh! No! You can't have them! He gave them to me, they're mine to play with! In the cold north, the night reigns. And then they'll kill me! A big happy family we are! Come, come, I'll show you!
Who are you?
None of your concern! I'm just an old man!
Nothing.
Co chceš?
Septon Germund sent me.
Is that so? What does the old knave want? More saffron, or is it one of Lord Manderlys nieces he's got his eye on this time? Or perhaps a cousin? Heh.

No. He sent me to track down a band of wildlings that had burned the village of Hillhall. My journey ended north of the Dreadfort, in the Lonely Hills, where I found the wildlings. They where cold as ice, yet still they walked. Their eyes where blue, without life. They where wights.
We had a raven from the Lord Commander... Thought for sure that Aemons wits must have been wandering, but if you saw the same in the Hills...

Hear me well, {playername}. I'm a learned man, and I've spent many of my years in the cellars of Castle Black, looking over the old books. Wights are not supposed to be able to pass beneath the Wall. It's not just ice and stone. Powerful magic was used to raise it, and it still holds to this day. These wights must have been reanimated here, not beyond the Wall.
They where. I slew the man who did it.
Gods be good! Return to Septon Germund at once, {playername}. He must be made to spread the word. The villagers must be armed. The Wall must hold!
I forgot.
Yes, {playername}?
I found the wildlings. An old man had raised them from the dead, as wights!

This is dire news, {playername}! The Seven-Pointed Star warns of wights and revenants, shades and snarks! We must arm the villages, and warn the lords! And someone must send a raven to the Wall... Gueren can do that! And make sure our fires burn brigt! Speaking of fire, I have something that might come in handy, should you run into more of these creatures.
Where did you get these?

Before I became a septon, I studied with the pyromancers of King's Landing. Old fools the lot of them! When I left them, I took these pots with me. Been a real nuisance having to transport them everywhere in barrels of sand, I tell you that! Be careful with them, they can't be refilled! And I certainly can't make any more of the substance!
I forgot.
Greetings {playername}.
Greetings to you too.
Yes? What do you want? Be quiet, or the young lord will be startled!. Wouldn't do to have him startled, he makes a mess when he twitches.
Do you know of anyone who would happen to have a task for me?
The lady Lysa is the ruler of the Vale until young lord Robert comes of age. Seek an audience with her. She is currently sleeping, but come back later and I'm sure she'll find time for you.
What?
Be quiet! You'll wake the baby! What do you want?
I am {playername}, my lady, and I've come seeking adventure. Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.

Yes, {playername}, I do, I do. Those vile mountain clans have been causing all sort of chaos lately! Not three days ago, they assaulted a septa and her ward. Slew the brave knight guarding them. I wonder how they've gotten their hands on such pristine weapons... They need to be dealt with! The Vale will know what a strong and just lord they have!
What can I do?
Go out there and kill them, obviously! Talk to Ser Albar, Lord Nestors son. He'll know what to do, I'm sure.
Where can I find him?
Oh, how should I know? Do I have to do everything myself! Go look for him at the Bloody Gate, he often goes hunting there.
Very well, I'll return once the clans have been dealt with.
Yes?
I'm busy, go away!
Are you Ser Albar Royce?
Yes, what's it to you?
My name is {playername}. Lady Lysa sent me here, she believes you can help me dealing with the mountain clans.

Hah! A hundred generations of Arryns have tried to deal with those damn savages, I doubt you'll be able to do anything about them. The lady Lysa is a good and honest woman, but... she is, shall we say, prone to bouts of extreme optimism when dealing with matters like this. Still, I guess teaching the clans a lesson wouldn't be the worst we could do.
So you know where they are?

Gods no! If I knew, I'd have gone after them myself. No one knows where they live, that's why they're never dealt with. The Mountains of the Moon are filled with caves and hidden valleys... Still, try and visit Jharys in Gulltown. He sometimes has dealings with the clans, but we let him get away with it because he helps us track down kidnapped maidens.
Hmph!
Co chceš?
Are you Jharys?
Yes, yes, what's it to you?
Albar Royce seemed to think you might know where I could find the mountain clans.

Hah, which one? There's a dozen! And no, I don't know where they are. Perhaps Ser Myles over at Coldwater Burn has heard something. That man is the biggest gossip, and drunk, in the Vale of Arryn. He knows everything.
You've been most helpful.
No matter, I'm leaving.
What do you want, huh?
Ser Myles? Jharys sent me, he told me you might know where to find the mountain clans?

Oh no, haven't got a clue about them clans. Heard a juicy rumour about Mychel Redfort and Lyn Corbray recently though, and one about that singer at the lady Lysas court. Seems he's rather fond of young maidens, especially those yet to be spoiled by another man! But no, I have no idea where the mountain clans live.
Do you know any who might?
Not really, no. Though perhaps... perhaps you could go ask my mother, lady Barbrey. She lives in Wickenden.
Big help you are!
Thank you, Ser Myles.
Bah!
Don't mention it.
Nothing, I'm leaving.
Grarh!
What?
Die, tiny warrior!
Co chceš?
Lady Barbrey, your son sent me, he thinks you might know where to find the mountain clans?

Bah, did he now! Could have told you himself, couldn't he? His father is the chief of one of those savage clans. Calls themselves the Moon Brothers. Bah! Guess you're done talking to me now, am I right? No one wants to talk to me ever since those savages returned me to my fathers keep, violated and big with child... Last I heard, the Moon Brothers had been seen close to Strongsong...
Thank you.
Zapomeň na to...
May I know more about you, my lady?
No! Go away, and tell that drunken bastard son of mine he's as worthless as that pig of a father who begot him!
Nothing.
Co chceš?
I've come looking for the Moon Brothers, have you heard anything?
Yes, they where spotted not a mile from here! But we don't have the numbers to deal with them. As of late, the clans have grown wilder, and they bear sharp steel and heavy armor!
I'll head out right away, and deal with them!
You'll do that now, will you?
Well, I guess you might as well give it a go. I don't imagine you'll return, but here's a small parting gift. Never let it be said that the men of Strongsong don't reward bravery.
Thank you.
My pleasure. I do hope you can do something about these savages.
I forgot.
I've slain the Moon Brothers, one less tribe of clansmen to trouble the Vale.

Trying to steal Ser Albars glory, eh? He came to me not an hour ago and told me how he and his knights had tracked down the savages and taught them who rules the Vale. I'll not have liars at the Eyrie, away with you! Just you wait till Lord Nestor hears of this!
Erh...
Go away!
Ah, {playername}! It's good to see you again!
Haldon mentioned that you might have further need of my skills.

Yes, {playername}, I do, I do. I need someone to take a message to a friend of mine, in King's Landing. You know King's Landing, I assume? That big heap of fleas and poor souls strangling the mouth of the Blackwater Rush. Can't miss it, and even if you do, the smell will remind you that you're close.
Where can I find him?
Excuse me, I have important matters that require my attention.
Oh, he's usually to be found in the Black Cells of the Red Keep. Outside them though, not inside. Works as an undergaoler in the cells.
What is his name? How do I know whether I'm talking to the right person?
On second thought, I think I'll stay out of this.

My friend goes by the name of Rugen. I suppose he'll be dressed as a gaoler. Gaolers usually are. Helps mark them for what they are, that is. Gaolers, nothing else. How could a man dressed as a gaoler be anything but a gaoler.
Very well, I'll bring Rugen your message.
I can't carry that right now.
Yes?
Yes?
Are you Rugen?
My name is {playername}. I've been sent by Illyrio Mopatis, all the way from Pentos, to bring you a message.
Ah, yes, the message. Hmph, well done {playername}. Let's keep this between us, eh? Here's a bit of... ah... incentive.
Do you need me to bring back a message?
Well, ah, if you're headed back to Pentos, you might as well bring him my, ah, reply. You'll need to keep quiet about your doings, obviously.
Very well.
I can't carry that right now.
Yes {playername}?
Rugen asked me bring you his reply.
Ah splendid, {playername}. You've been a great help. Would you be interested in doing me yet another favor?
Yes.

I need you to bring a chest of... valuables... to an acquaintance of mine. A knight, by the name of Rolly Duckfield. I've arranged for him to wait in a tavern in Norvos. Bring him the chest, and I'll make sure you're well rewarded.
Very well.
I can't carry that right now.
No matter, I'm leaving.
What do you want, huh?
Ser Rolly? Magister Illyrio asked me to bring you this chest.

Ah good, good. But Griff says our plans have changed, and I'm afraid I can't carry this with me if we're going to get the boy to Selhorys in time. You'll need to return this to Magister Illyrio, with my apologies.
Who are you talking about? Take it back?
Ah shit. Nevermind. Just bring the chest back to Pentos, and talk with the fat man. Tell him we're heading west instead of east.
I'm not a pack mule!
Very well.
Bah!
Thanks, friend.
Nothing, I'm leaving.
Yes, {playername}? How very good to see you. Did you get the chest to Norvos?
I did, but your friend had me bring it back here.
What? Why? Did he give you a reason. Speak man.
He said something about a boy, Selhorys and going west?

Curse that man! Griff is too impatient! We've been keeping him secret for sixteen years, and now we're running out of time?! We'll have to act quickly, {playername}. Go back to King's Landing and tell Rugen what you've learned. No, better yet, bring him this letter.
Very well.
I'm afraid I can't carry a letter right now.
Nothing.
Co chceš?
I'm looking for a man named Rugen.
Ah, Rugen! An unsavory fellow. Not like myself. I'm of royal blood myself, you see.
What are you talking about?

I'm descended from the natural born son of a Targaryen princess. My mother told me the story. My ancestor was such a strong, brave and handsome warrior, that even a princess could fall in love with him. She told me he was a captain of a ship, a man who braved even the storms of the Cape of Wrath.

Their son was born a bastard, but a royal bastard! My fathers father added the 'Long' before 'Waters'. We're a noble family of knights carrying royal blood, you see. Couldn't have a name as lowborn as 'Waters'!
Oh, I don't care! Do you know where Rugen is?
He's in the tavern. I swear it on my royal blood!
I forgot.
Ah, {playername}.
Magister Illyrio asked me to deliver this letter to you.
Well, ah, then. Give it here.
Well?
I am in your debt, {playername}. Here, please accept this gift as a sign of my gratitude.
If you don't mind me asking, who is Griff?

Ah, {playername}, you'll know in time, in time. Suffice to say, the men of the Sunset Kingdoms are all the same. They sew some beast upon a scrap of silk, and suddenly they are all lions or stags or eagles, but black or red, a dragon is still a dragon. But ah, I need you to do one last thing for me...
I need you to visit a winesink in Sunspear, called the Thirsty Goat. Look for a man called Septon Allard, and deliver the letter to him.
Very well.
Zapomeň na to.
What?
I bring a sealed letter from Rugen.
Do you now... give it to me.
Here you are.
Hmm...
The prince must hear of this. Visit the castle and deliver this letter to Maester Caleotte.
Erm, I will...
I can't carry that right now.
Good.
I forgot.
Yes?
I was told to bring you this.
Ah yes... {playername}, Magister Illyrio speaks highly of you in this letter, you've done the prince a great service.
I'm glad.
Hmm...

It seems to me that the magister did not offer you a suitable reward for the great risks you've faced... I will make sure you receive a proper reward, on the understanding that not a word of what you've accomplished for us ever leave your mouth... Words are like arrows, once loosened you cannot call them back, and one stray arrow can bring down even a prince.
I won't speak a word of what I've done.
Good, good. Accept this as a proper reward for your accomplishments then, {playername}, and remember your vow. The storm is on the horizon.
I forgot.
Yes, can I help you?
I'm looking for the castellan, have you seen him?
Ser Rodrik rode into the woods this morning, but he should be back soon.
Excuse me, I'm very busy.
Welcome to Winterfell. Can I help you?
Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.
Yes, I do. If you're man enough for it.
What would you have me do?
The Bastard of Bolton has been wrecking havock across the Lonely Hills. For his crimes, he has been sentenced to death. I need someone who can bring the kings justice to this monster of a man.
Hmm... Is there a reward for this task?
Farewell.
Indeed there is. Bring about the Bastards demise, and I will grant you a fair reward.
Very well, I will bring the kings justice to Ramsay Snow.
I am not interested.
Yes?
What do you want? Leave me be, peasant, I have no time for beggars.
Ramsay Snow, by order of ser Rodrik Cassel, castellan of Winterfell, I sentence you to die.
What? I'll teach you to call me 'Snow'! Do you truly think you can harm me here, in my lord fathers castle?
No, but you will have to leave eventually. When you do, you die.
Maybe it'll be you choking on your own blood! I will hurt you, I will flay you, and when I am done with you, you'll beg for death!
Hmph!
I'll flay the skin off your wretched body!
We'll see about that!
I'll make you regret this!
Yes?
Ser Rodrik, I've taken care of the Bastard for you. He shouldn't be a threat any longer.
Truly? Winterfell and the North is in your debt, {playername}. Ramsay Snow was not a man, he was a beast wearing a mans skin. I'll see to it that you'll be rewarded for this deed.
My pleasure, Ser Rodrik. If you've any other tasks that need doing, please let me know.
May I know more about you?
I am Rodrik Cassel, castellan and master-at-arms at Winterfell.
Zapomeň na to.
I am Septon Garibald. May the Father Above watch over you. Now, how can I help you?
Do you have any tasks for me?

No, not right now, but I've heard that one of the tenants of Cairnhall has been seeking a knight to get rid of an, erm, wight... or a grumkin. Who can tell what goes on in a peasants mind. He has made his home in the tavern. I also overheard Lord Swanns captain of the guards, Ser Clifford Gower, talk about some letters he needs delivered to some minor lord. Ser Clifford went out hunting this morning, but he should be back in a few hours. Ah, and yes, if you have the time, {playername}, I need a letter delivered to archmaester Harodon at the Citadel in Oldtown.
Very well.
I can't carry a letter right now.
I'm busy.
Welcome to the Iron Bank. How can I be of service?
Yes, {playername}?
I want to discuss my finances.
Farewell.

Very well. You do not yet have an account with us. We will gladly help you deposit whatever amount of coin you desire here with us. You can retrieve your gold whenever you so desire, and we are currently offering a 5% return rate on deposits. Is that acceptable?
Your current balance is {reg1} coins. What do you want to do?
[Deposit 100 coins]
[Deposit 1000 coins]
[Deposit 10000 coins]
[Retrieve 100 coins]
[Retrieve 1000 coins]
[Retrieve 10000 coins]
Never mind.
That is acceptable.
That is all I wanted to know.
Very well. Welcome to the Iron Bank of Braavos.
What is it? I'm busy! All these acolytes, with their stupid questions!
Archmaester Harodon? Septon Garibald told me to deliver this letter to you.
Farewell.
Oh who cares. Another septon, preaching to us about how our efforts are futile, that all truth lies with the Father Above. Bah! Bunch of sheep is what they are!
What do you mean?

The Faith has been trying to curb our influence for hundreds of years. Feel like they should be the only ones spreading knowledge. Or their version of it, at least. Sheep is what they are, shackled in their huts of ignorance. Did you know that Baelor the Blessed was considering a request to bring the Citadel under the authority of the High Septon when he died? Good thing his uncle killed him, Viserys was a much better king. Didn't know that, did you? Oh, there's no written evidence, but sure as rain, Viserys murdered Baelor and took the throne.
Very well...
Do you believe in the Seven, {playername}? That the Father Above watches you, the Warrior protects you, the Crone lights the way?
I do.
I do not.
Then to you I say 'bahhh'. Go rut around in the mud with the other sheep, and leave us enlightened men to continue our work.

Ah, a learned men is what you are then. Well done I say. Too many superstitious fools rut around in the mud, always looking for answers they'll never find. Marwyn could tell you all about what it's like to rut around down there.
Yes?
Yes? How can I help you?
Who are you?
Farewell.

An Archmaester of the Citadel! Though there's plenty of us around, these days the conclave will give any man who's read a book the title. Just look at Harodon. Bigger fool you'd have to search for far and wide. The Faith can be niggardly, stubborn, backwards and cruel, but the septons still hold more power than we'll ever do, advisers of lords and ladies though we are. It's unwise to antagonize those with more power than yourself.

You won't hear me defend the septons though. They've burned more books than I care to think about. Imagine what we would know of the past, if it wasn't for Baelor Targaryen. All those books, gone, and for what? Some silly king, half a boy, who fancied himself more than a man, more than a king. Baelor saw himself as the embodiement of the Seven, a god made flesh.
Very well...

It's all here in the books. The evidence. You just have to look for it. Plenty of people don't. They'll read some asinine book meant for bored lords and ladies, and think they understand the way the world works. But without proper training, how will they ever be able to see the world for what is really is. Bah, nothing worse than some uneducated know-it-all. But ah, enough of the rabble. More important things are afoot in the world. Did you know that the Citadel is always looking for lost works? Books, scrolls, ledgers. Would you be interested in procuring such items for us, {playername}?
I am interested.

Ah, good. Books are precious, you know. A single copy of Barths 'Unnatural History' would be worth more than a sword of valyrian steel. Imagine that, {playername}! Alas, Baelor was thorough in destroying all of Barths writings. But enough about that. If you want to help us conserve the knowledge of the past, travel to King's Landing. The Citadel employs a procurer in the city, who always scours the bookshops for unknown writings, but he often needs men who can travel further from the city and pick up books from other places. His name is Malko, you can find him on Coppersmith's Wynd. He runs a shop called 'Malkos Bookstore'. No one ever required the man to have a bit of imagination, but still...
I am not interested.
Ano?
Ah, a customer! How can I help you, my good man?
I've been sent by Archmaester Harodon.
Farewell.

Joyous news! My last procurer had a nasty accident a couple of months back. Cut himself on a fine piece of vellum, and would you believe it, it turned gangrenous! Lost his whole hand. Sad story, so sad. At least it wasn't his right hand, he'll still be able to work as a scribe...
What does a procurer do?

They procure books. I have many contacts throughout the Seven Kingdoms, and you wouldn't believe the kind of lost knowledge the lords and knights of the realm have hidden away in their cellars. Once, I found a piece of Septon Barth's 'Dragons, Wyrms and Wyverns: Their Unnatural History' being used as a tablecloth in the room of an old blind knight. Sold it to Tyrion Lannister for a king's ransom. Even the Citadel itself cannot outbid a Lannister. But they are my most persistent customers, the maesters.
But what do you need me for?

I can't leave my shop to go gallivanting around the world looking for books, but I can't send a soft scribe in my place either. Even at the best of times, the roads can be hazardous. But you look like a tough sort, and I have work for someone tough. I've heard rumours of a book, hidden away in the Vale. It might be multiple books to tell you the truth. It's referenced in various texts, most notably in one of Barth's fragments. It goes by different names. The Dreams of Azathoth. Dead Names. But it's most often called The Mysteries of the Worm. Who knows which one is real. I think it's a myth, but imagine if not! We could sell the book to the maesters for unimaginable riches!
It's very valuable?

Ah, not really. Marwyn writes that the people of Asshai tell tales of the book. It's supposed to be an introduction to all kinds of magic. Silly superstitions. But the maesters have labored long and hard to eradicate supposed 'magical' textbooks, and a find such as this could render many of their efforts futile. So they'd pay well to have it destroyed. According to my sources, a septon has been making mentions of a magical book in the north-western parts of the Vale. Go there and talk to him, {playername}, find out if there's any truth to the whole thing. I'll reward you handsomely, and here's a bit of an advance.
Yes?
A blessing, my good man? The Father Above is all the protection you need. Lay down your weapons and rejoice in his holy light.
I'm looking for a book.
Farewell.
What book?...
The Mysteries of the Worm?

Never heard of it. Only book a godly man need is The Seven-Pointed Star. Everything else is just worldly knowledge, soon to be forgotten. Why waste your time with books about plants when you could show your devotion to the Seven instead?
So you haven't heard anything about a book? It's supposed to be rare.
Haven't heard anything about much lately. This is a remote corner of the world, my little place of worship. The smallfolk around here are simple, with simple needs and simple dreams.
Do you know anyone who might have knowledge of books in the area?

Can't say I do. Though perhaps Ser Elston have heard something. His holdings are to the east of here, close to the foot of the mountains. We're very isolated here, but if anyone have heard anything about books, it's either Ser Elston or his maester.
Yes?
Terrible weather, isn't it? It feels... sour. Somethings wrong with it.
What do you mean?
Farewell.

This whole place is... wrong. Should have stayed on the road. Never wanted this. I'm Ser Elston Boone, the last of House Boone. Inherited these holdings from a distant cousin last year. Used to be a tourney knight. What a life, riding from town to town, not a care in the world. Now I'm shackled to this place.
I'm looking for a rare book, and was wondering if I might consult with your maester?

The Mysteries of the Worm? I can see from your reaction that's the one. Cadwyn has not been talking about anything else for weeks. Found it mentioned in some old papers left behind by one of my ancestors. Mentioned something about Witch Isle and the Upcliffs. Cadwyn was sure he could figure out where the book went... Did you hear that?! There's something in the walls. Perhaps it's just rats... but they'd have to be a monstrous size...
Can I talk to maester Cadwyn?
Afraid not, {playername}.
Why not?

He killed himself. Two days ago. Cut his own throat. Bad way to go. It's this sour air. It turns everyone mad. He rambled for days you know. Shouting about the Long Night. About great white spiders and wights walking up and down a wall... his trip to the barrow changed him... should never visit barrows, {playername}, the dead sleep better when not disturbed...
Yes?
Ah, {playername}! Tell me, did you find the book?
I did not.
Farewell.
Oh, what a shame. Just a rumor then, nothing to it? I hear all kinds of stories, most of them untrue. You wouldn't believe the nonsense tales that originate in remote hamlets.
I did hear of a fragment of the book.
You did? Tell me more!

A maester found a clue or a sliver of notes partaining to it. I tried to find where it was, but all I found was a crazed man who had sacrificed to an old tree. He'd written the name 'YGG' on a stone, with the blood of one of his victims.

'Ygg', you say? How quaint. The ironborn tell tales of how their legendary ruler, The Grey King, carved the first longship from a tree called Ygg. Supposively, a demon lived in the tree, a demon with the power of foresight. Anyone who had their future told by Ygg would inevitable meet with tragedy. Ygg always chose to tell the future in a way that would cause the most pain to the world.
Is the story true?

Ah, not really. How could it be. A demon living in a tree? Sounds like the maester you mentioned got caught up in some fancy tale of his own. But forget about that, {playername}. At least you tried to find the book. That's worth a reward.
Yes?
Yes? Can I help you?
Ser Clifford? Septon Garibald told me you had need of someone to deliver a letter?
Farewell.

Ah yes, I do. The maiden daughter of Symond Templeton, the Knight of Ninestars, is turning thirteen this next moon, and Ser Symonds uncles have decided to hold a tourney in her honor. My late wife was a Templeton by birth, making the young girl my niece by marriage. I've been invited to attend the melee, but my duties keep me here. However, I was always fond of my lady wife, and for her sake, I wish to send a name day present to the young girl.
What can I do?

Take this letter, and this ruby ring which belonged to my lady wife, and deliver them to the castellan of Ninestars, he'll make sure the young maid receives them. Be mindful, however, that you do not upset her uncles - they're a querulous bunch. I'll make sure you're compensated for your troubles, {playername}, obviously.
Very well, I'll do it.
I'm afraid I can't carry all that now.

Splendid! With all the chaos engulfing the realm, I imagine this will be the last great tourney in quite a while. While you're in the Vale, you should take the time to enjoy yourself. This summer has lasted a long time already, there's no knowing how much time we have left before winter arrives and we all have to huddle around our fires.
Very well, I'll take a look at the tourney while I'm there.
Yes?
Yes? Can I help you?
My lord? I'm looking for the castellan. I've brought a gift and letter from Ser Clifford Gower.

Oh well, I'm the castellan of Ninestars, so you've found your man. Ser Clifford you say? By the Seven, we haven't heard from him in years. How is the old rogue doing? Oh, nevermind, how would you know. You said something about a gift? And a letter? I doubt Rowena can even remember Ser Clifford, not with all those great-uncles of hers taking up all her time and attention. Ser Symonds father had seven brothers, can you believe that?! Boisterous and arrogant the lot of them.
Here's the letter and the gift.

Ah, thank you {playername}, I do appreciate it. The young lady will surely enjoy this gift, the ring is an old family heirloom. I'll make sure she receives them right away. Say, while you're here, you should take a stroll around the grounds. A great many merchants and mummers have camped outside the walls, and they're sure to provide a great spectacle and much merriment.
I'll do that.

Good, good. Do stay around for the tourney, will you? We haven't had as many visitors as we hoped. The mountain clans have grown wild, and many knights and lords have decided to stay in their keeps and holdfasts, rather than risking the roads. It was different when Jon Arryn ruled the Vale, then those vile savages wouldn't have dared show their face unless they had ten times the numbers we do!
Very well, I'll take a look at the tourney while I'm there.
Yes?

{playername}. What where you thinking? The knight you attacked is Ser Raymun Templeton, Ser Symonds youngest uncle. What a mess, the man is infuriated. Let me ask you this, {playername}, how good of a fighter are you?
I can hold my own.

Doesn't say much, does it? What a vague answer. You're a guest here, {playername}, and an unknown one at that. You struck a relative of the Knight of Ninestars, outside his own castle. Ser Symond would be in his right to cut off the offending hand. But Ser Raymun was never his favorite uncle, nor is he a friend of mine, so it's been agreed that you will be judged by someone other than Ser Symond. As it happens, I will be one of the three judges at your trial.
Then why are you here?

Why indeed. Ser Raymun and I have never been fast friends. To tell you the truth, I despise the man. However, the other two judges are his brothers. I'm the castellan of Ninestars, and a knight of House Tollett, my word carries weight in these parts, and I will urge the judges to be merciful. However, you struck the youngest brother of the two other judges, so there's a risk you'll wake up tommorow without a hand. There is another option, though.
Tell me.

You stand accused of assaulting a relative of the Knight of Ninestars. The judges will be unlikely to look upon your case with favorable eyes. But if you demand a trial by combat, you might be able to prevail. So I ask you again, {playername}, how good of a warrior are you?
I see.
Sleep on it, {playername}, the trial starts tommorow.

{playername}! Hah! Did you see the look on Raymuns face? That bastard got a surprise there, no denying it. But can you defeat him? I admit, I know nothing about you, except for your ability to hit knights right on the nose. Are you a knight yourself?
Yes.
No.

Oh well, that makes everything so much easier. A knight! Really? Splendid. Do you have own armor? Sword, helmet, horse? Ah well, either way, I would be honored if you'd let me provide all you need. {playername}, during the trial, did you notice how some of the knights and ladies seemed to approve of your request? Ser Raymun is not well loved, and there's been stories... peasant girls have complained before... either way, I think that not only the smallfolk but a great part of the nobles will be on your side during this fight. Why, you ask? Well, a knight is sworn to protect the weak. You remembered those vows.

Oh well, I guess it doesn't matter. Do you have own armor? Sword, helmet, horse? Ah well, either way, I would be honored if you'd let me provide all you need. {playername}, during the trial, did you notice how some of the knights and ladies seemed to approve of your request? Ser Raymun is not well loved, and there's been stories... peasant girls have complained before... either way, I think that not only the smallfolk but a great part of the nobles will be on your side during this fight.
I suppose so.

Do you know the rules of trial by combat, {playername}? The fight ends when either party yields or is killed, or when the accuser takes back his accusation, or when the accused declares himself guilty. You'll need to either kill Ser Raymun, or force him to yield and withdraw his accusations.
Very well.
I don't imagine there's much more to say. The trial is tommorow, I suggest you get some sleep. Ser Raymun was never a great warrior, but he's not unskilled either.
I see.
Sleep on it, {playername}, the trial starts tommorow.
Yes? Can I help you?
Are you from Cairnhall?
Farewell.
Ah yes, yes, I am Tom, the Elder sent me here to find a knight, true and honorable!
Erm, yes... Septon Garibald said you'd been having problems with a... wight?

Yes, yes, a revenant, a wight, a ghost! Saw it myself, only three weeks ago! Pale and with red eyes, it was flying through the night, in a crate made of bones! Made me shiver, make no mistake! The men of the village agreed with me, we need an faithful man to slay the beast, a knight, like Aemon the Dragonknight, from the stories!
Hmm... perhaps I could take a look at this wight myself.
Farewell.
Are you a knight? Oh, I'm sorry, of course you are! My father always told me the city was full of knights! Go to my village and slay the revenant, brave Ser! It haunts the old cairn, sure as day!
Very well, I'll go have a look.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes?
Have you seen a wight about here?
Hmph!

By the Seven, another one? Look, I'm not a wight, as I tried to tell that screaming girl when she came up here. I've been sent here by the Citadel to do some excavating, and I'll be gone in a day or two. This cairn really is a marvelous treasure trove. Found a cache of scrolls from before the Conquest, and tablets speaking of the Battle of the Bloody Pool.
You seem to have caused quite a stir in the village. Why didn't you just explain to them what you where doing here.

Ah, but then I'd have to explain to them what 'excavating' means, and before you know it, they're coming to me to bless their cows, heal their wounds and wed their daughters. Keep ignorant peasants away from me, and I can die a happy man.
Yes, {playername}?
Tom, I've taken care of the... wight.

Truly? Well done, Ser! I knew a true knight would have no trouble dealing with such a demon! Any man who is shrouded in his faith can withstand such a beast, the septon was right! Here, please take this, as a thank you!
Thank you, Tom.
Can you tell me more about Cairnhall?
Well... we grow a lot of beets... turnips too, now that I think about it.
Zapomeň na to.
Who are you?
I'm here to forge my chain and become grandmaester... Say, are you looking for work? Maester Yandel said he was looking for a courier.
What?
Yes? Can I help you?
Are you Yandel?
Farewell.
Ah yes, yes, I am Yandel. Who are you, and how can I help you?
One of the acolytes said you where looking for a courier?

Ah yes, quite, quite. I do. I have been working on a momentous tome these past years. I call it 'The World of Ice and Fire'. Beautiful work. Dedicated to king Robert, but now I suppose it should be dedicated to his heir... Either way, some of the illuminators in Lannisport have been working on a copy for the king. They do great work there, letters in gold and scarlet like you wouldn't believe. And I especially enjoy their work on sigils, it's like the krakens are getting ready to strangle the reader!
And?
Farewell.

Ah, I need someone to pick it up and deliver it to me. They're excellent craftsmen in Lannisport, but before I have the tome delivered to the king, I should like to check it for spelling errors. Wouldn't do to let the king be disappointed! And to tell you the truth, I quite enjoy looking at the pictures. Can you pick up the book? I'd do it myself, but I can't bear to be gone from the archives for long. So many mysteries! I'll make sure you're rewarded for your troubles.
Very well, I'll go get the tome.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes?
I'm here to pick up a tome for Maester Yandel.
Hmph!

Ah yes, very good. The ink finished drying not three days ago. It's quite beautiful, and I'm sure the king will be pleased. We used the same scarlet as the one Lord Tywin had us use for his invitation to the wedding of the king and queen, Lannister colors you know. That will be 500 coins for the work we've done. The Citadel has already paid for the materials.
Very well.

Here we are! The finest book ever made, I'd say. I had a look through it while the apprentices worked. The craftsmanship is like nothing anyones ever seen before, but you must give my regards to Yandel. The text is quite interesting as well.
I can't afford that.
Yes, {playername}?
I've returned with the tome.

Ah, very well. Yes, this is beautiful work indeed. Those apprentices know what they're about. Look at those dragons, it's almost as if you can feel the heat coming off them. Here's a little recompense for your troubles, {playername}.
Thank you.
Zapomeň na to.
Well met, {playername}.
How do you know my name?

I am Gueren, a brother of the Night's Watch. Gerold told me about you, {playername}, and how you handled that mad bastard up in the old holdfast. The latest raven from Aemon told of troubles at the Wall, perhaps you could head up there and see what's going on. Or maybe take the black yourself, the Wall is not picky.
The Wall must not fall, {playername}.
Yes? Who is it? Can I help you?
Maester Aemon? Gueren said you'd been having some sort of trouble lately?
Farewell.

Ah, Gueren. Troubles he says. We're in dire need of help, {playername}. Lord Commander Mormont went north with near a third of our strength. Only a few have returned. The Watch is sorely weakened, and the realm is disunited and in chaos. We can expect no help from any of the kings.
How can I help?

One of our brothers, Jon, recently returned to us. He had been pretending to join the wildlings, and he has brought us valuable information of their whereabouts and intentions. Jon left the wildlings just south of Mole's Town, and we have every reason to believe they might still be somewhere in the area. Jon says they're led by a man named Styr, the Magnar of Thenn. Magnar means 'lord' in the Old Tongue, but even a lord amongst the wildlings will want to loot and burn a town such as Mole's Town.
Hmm... what do you want me to do?
Farewell.

We have assembled a force of men to intercept the Magnar and defeat his band of raiders, but Bowen Marsh has gone west to defend the Shadow Tower with the remaining part of the garrison, and we need someone to led them. Jon is still too weak to leave his bed, and Donal Noye must stay here to led the defenses. The rest of our brothers are eager, but they do not have the experience. Gerold mentioned your deeds in the Lonely Hills, and I trust his judgement. You must led the brothers of the Night's Watch against the Magnar, {playername}.
Very well, I will defeat the Magnar!
I am not interested.
Yes, {playername}?
Yes, {playername}? Is the Magnar dead?
The Magnar is dead.

Truly? This is joyous news, {playername}. You have bought us valuable time to arm ourselves against attack. While we prepare for the inevitable, I need someone to visit Eastwatch-by-the-Sea and tell Cotter Pyke of the events here. Will you do this?
I will, Maester Aemon.
May I know more about you?
Ah, {playername}, there is much and more to know, but none left to tell my story. Egg is long gone...
Zapomeň na to.
Yes? Who are you?
Maester Aemon sent me, with news from Castle Black.
Well, out with it then. I'm not some pampered knight, I feel no need to waste time with idle yammering.
The wildlings are approaching the wall. We stopped them in Mole's Town.

Well then, I guess we're saved for another day, eh? I don't see why Aemon couldn't send a raven with these news. Why are you here? Ah, I see. He wants me to send my men to Castle Black, to defend it against the attack? Just because that fool, Bowen Marsh, had to gallavant off to defend against an obvious diversion! Fine! Tell Aemon I'll send as many men as I can spare, I'll even send Emmett with them. The lads worth three experienced rangers.
Very well, I'll return to Aemon with these news.
Farewell.
Good! And tell Bowen he's a fool while you're at it!
Erh, yes...
I am not interested.
Yes, {playername}?
Farewell.
Yes, {playername}? What did Cotter Pyke say?
He's sending as many men as he can spare to aid us in the defense.

Good, good. It probably helps that Bowen is absent, he can't stand the man... {playername}, I need you to travel to the Shadow Tower, and visit Ser Denys, and see what has happened to Bowen Marsh and his men. They've been gone for a long time, and the men of the Shadow Tower can guard the Gorge as well as the men of Castle Black. We need them here, to defend the Wall against Mance Rayder.
Very well.
Can you tell me about Castle Black?
Ah, {playername}, I'm afraid you'll have to excuse me. Perhaps you could ask Clydas...
Zapomeň na to.
Yes? Who are you?
Maester Aemon sent me, for news of Bowen Marsh.

Ah, very well. But you're not my brother, are you? Ah, no matter, no matter, we need all the help we can get. Lord Marsh was well the last time I saw him, {playername}. He took most of my men to the Gorge, to guard the Bridge of Skulls.
The Bridge of Skulls?

Ah, you haven't heard of it. The Bridge is the only way across the Gorge, a large, well, gorge, very deep. The wildlings often descend the Gorge, to bypass the Wall. We'd had news that a large force of wildlings where in the area, so Lord Marsh took the greater part of our strength to defend the Bridge.
Cotter Pyke said Bowen Marsh was a fool for falling for the diversion?...
Farewell.

Cotter Pyke! Bah! The bastard son of a tavern wench, the most vile man in the entire Watch, an ironborn bastard, half a wildling himself! Still, I myself might not have been so quick to take the greater part of our strength with me to guard the Gorge... Ah, nothing to do about it now. In fact, {playername}, I'd greatly appreciate it if you where to head to the Gorge yourself. Should the wildlings attack, Lord Marsh could use all the help he can get!
I'll have a look at this Gorge!
I am not interested.
Yes, {playername}?
Farewell.
Yes, {playername}? How fares Lord Marsh?
The Weeper tried to force his away across, but we beat him back.

Good, good, {playername}. But the wildlings are sure to descend on Castle Black at any moment now, you must hurry back and lend whatever aid you can. The Wall has stood for eight thousand years, we'll make sure it still stands after this King-Beyond-the-Wall is in his grave.
Very well, Ser Denys.
Can you tell me about the Shadow Tower?
Ah, {playername}, I'm afraid you'll have to excuse me, Maester Mullin is the scholar here.
Nevermind.
{playername}. Is Bowen still alive?
Barely, Maester Aemon. What happened here?

Another party of wildlings attacked us, but we beat them back. Alas, the true battle has only just begun, {playername}. They have been digging throuhg the Wall, and they've managed to make a breach into one of the storerooms. The lower part of the wall is vulnerable in a very few places, if it had been anyone but Mance Rayder leading them, they would have never known where to dig.
What can I do?

Join the fight, {playername}. The stewards are holding the wall, raining down arrows on the wildlings. Jon has taken the remaining rangers and are holding off the wildlings in the tunnels beneath the Wall. Join him and defend the realm, {playername}.
Where is the breach?
Farewell.
Just west of here. Make haste!
For the realm!
I am not interested.
Yes, {playername}?
Farewell.
Yes? Ah, {playername}. What news do you bring?
We beat back the wildlings.

Ah, very well. But I fear our position is untenable. It would have been different if the Watch had been at full strength, but our forces have dwindled over the years... we face a position unlike any in our long history.
What do you mean?

Time and time again, the wildlings have thrown themselves against the Wall. Raymund Redbeard, Bael the Bard, Joramun... but this time, it is different. We are a shadow of our former selves, and the Stark in Winterfell has gone south. There is no one to defeat the wildlings when they make their final attack on the Wall.
But we beat them back in the tunnels!
Farewell.

A test, {playername}. Mance Rayder has men to spare, and we have none. We cannot hold them off, but we can continue the fight! You must go to Jon and tell him to evacuate Castle Black. A Lord Commander could never do so, but Lord Mormont is gone, and we've yet to chose a successor. I can order the brothers to go south, and join the northern lords in their holdfasts and castles. We have no commanding officers, and I am the oldest brother of the Night's Watch still alive. The high lords cannot accuse me of cowardice, no sane man would wish to live to my age.

But ah, before you go... a gift. When I joined the Order of Maesters, I forswore my old family name, but I have not forgotten it. When Bloodraven left for his last ranging, he entrusted me with the sword his father bestowed upon him. The sword that Aegon's sister Visenya wielded when she rode upon Meraxes, one of the three great dragons. The ancestral valyrian sword of House Targaryen! It is called Dark Sister, and its history is illustrious and proud. You must wield it now, {playername}, and defend the realm, as the kings should have.
I am honored, my lord.
I am not interested.
Yes, {playername}?
Farewell.
Yes?
Aemon has ordered you to abandon the Wall.

We're sworn to guard the realm! There’s no shame in fear, my father told me, what matters is how we face it... Arh, Maester Aemon has the right of it! We could throw away our lives here, and it would barely slow down Mance and his army! We'll retreat to Winterfell, and join the lords when they march on the wildlings.
For the realm!
Can we hold the Wall?
We're sworn to hold the Wall.
Zapomeň na to.
Yes? Another adventurer, come to our great city, eh? Looking for valyrian steel?
Tell me more.
The best craftman in the city is Elos Mott. He's the master of the Guild of Blacksmiths. If you're interested in valyrian steel, talk to him.
Good luck.
Yes? I am Elos Mott, leader of the Blachsmiths of Qohor, most gifted of all the craftsmen in the world. Welcome to my shop.
Cetherys said you could tell me about valyrian steel?
Farewell.

Ah, the bane of my existence! Everyone wants to know about valyrian steel. Why, I ask, when one could also learn about tinted metals, armor strong enough to withstand the blow of a warhammer, or even the precious substance the alchemists call wildfire. But no! Always valyrian steel... travellers and adventurers, princes and archons, they all come asking about the steel of Valyria.

What would you have me tell you, that no one does not already know. Valyrian steel is precious. A drunk in a tavern could tell you that. Valyrian steel is indestructable. The same drunk would tell you the same truth. Valyrian steel is the rarest material in the world, worth lordships and fiefdoms. All the drunks in the world know this.

But can I, the master of blacksmiths, reforge valyrian steel? Yes. I can. Can I make new valyrian steel. Well... time will soon tell. Remember the fate of Maester Pol, and do not inquire into my work, or the work of my colleagues. The city watch will have you if you do, and so will the disciples of the Black Goat.
But you can reforge valyrian steel?
Farewell.

Yes, I can. Any member of the guild can. However, we do not provide the steel. Even if we had such materials at hand, Tywin Lannister has already paid us good, solid, gold to reserve it for him. No, {playername}, I will gladly reforge a blade for you, but you will need to gather the materials yourself. We once forged a new blade for the lysene nobleman Moredo Rogare. Truth, he called it. It was forged from four daggers of valyrian steel, and the cost was enough to outfit an entire fleet of ships. Gather enough daggers, and I will be able to forge for you a new blade of pure, indestructable, valyrian steel, worthy of a king, a prince, even a dragonlord.
Very well.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes? Ah, you again. {playername}, I really do not have anything else to tell you about valyrian steel...
I have gathered the four daggers.
Farewell.

Truly? That is quite wonderous, {playername}, I did not think that would be possible unless you where to sack one of the other Free Cities. You did not do this deed, no? No sacking of those heathens occured in the search for these daggers, I can rest easy, yes?

Ah yes, these daggers are exquisite indeed. Forged in the fires of the Freehold. But ah! Forged anew in Qohor, the greatest of the Free Cities, heir to Old Valyria! The Black Goat will surely appreciate our sacrifice, and grant us the good fortune that we may create a blade such as the world has never seen before.

Now, while these daggers certainly are of valyrian steel, they are not overly large. I can create a blade for you, but I cannot extend the metal or supplant it. You will have to be content with a short sword, but a sword it will certainly be. I can fashion it into whatever shape you desire. Which would that be?
I desire a blade with a curved crossguard.
I desire a blade fit for stabbing.
I desire a short arming sword.
Farewell.

Very well. I shall craft you such a blade. The process is laborous and costly. I do not haggle, and will name my price once the blade is ready. Return to me shortly, and the blade shall be ready for you.
Very well.
Yes?

Welcome, welcome, traveller, to the Alchemist's Bend! Built in shadows by a sinister cabal of sorcerers and magi! According to the smallfolk. It wasn't really, you know. The last Hightower king, Lymond the Sea Lion, built it. How can I help you?
I'm looking to buy some valyrian steel.
Farewell.
Truly? Why, I have a huge pile just lying over here, by the basket of apples!

Hah! No, I don't. Valyrian steel... We do have some, it's true, but it's locked away down in the vaults, and I doubt Marwyn would part with the key. What would you need it for, anyhow? If you're considering becoming an acolyte, you can earn your own link in time...

Ah, I just realised, {playername}, that I do not care that much. This is the workshop where we do delicate work, and I really have to get back to the forge. What can I do for you that will make you leave?
Tell me where to find valyrian steel.
Farewell.

Fine. Take this list. Archmaester Mollos compiled it a couple of years ago. Gods knows why. It was part of a larger treatise on daggers... but still. Say, do you plan to visit the blacksmiths of Qohor? Pol did once. They are monsters. They reforge valyrian steel, it's true, but to do so, they practice blood magic. Blood sacrifice, slaves and infants slaughtered on the altar of the Black Goat.
Thank you.
I am not interested.
Yes?

Ah, {playername}. A joyous day, this. We have made something not often seen since the Doom came to Valyria so many years ago. Praise be to the Black Goat, the Harbinger, the Whisper in the Darkness, the Worm that Doth Come.
So it is done then?
Farewell.

It is done, and a fine blade it is. Our craft has grown stronger as of late, and the candles are once again burning. The Black Goat certainly has favored us in this endeavor, and we in return have sacrificed to the most fearsome of gods. Now there is the matter of our payment. We shall require 20000 coins for this most magnificent weapon, as the process of crafting it is not without its cost. Is this agreeable?
It is.
It is.
It is.
Not right now.
Very good. If you should ever happen upon more steel, return to us and we will continue our work together, and make the secrets of Old Valyria unravel before us.
Very well.
Nemám zájem.
Yes?
Do you have any tasks for me?
Hah, yes, go bugger yourself. Or go see Lord Tyrion, you look the right sort for the work he offers. He's probably in the tower.
Fuck off.
Yes? Can I help you? I suppose you've come here at the behest of Bronn? The man's been sending me all kinds of queer folk to me these past days, sellswords and rogues the lot of them.
Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.
Ah yes, I do. Tasks I have aplenty. The city lacks food, soldiers, weapons and proper queens, but I have more tasks than I know what to do with.
What would you have me do?

Most of the lords of the Crownlands have sworn their allegiance to the king, but those close to the sea have been... unreliable in their support. Ser Jeffory Darke has not seen fit to appear at court, and has been riding around the countryside, spreading rumors of Joffreys parentage. It won't do. Look at the boy, it's clear who his father is.
What do you want me to do?
Farewell.

The lords need to know that we won't tolerate such behavior. Ser Jefforys uncle was the one who alerted us to his nephews behavior. The king has seen fit to sentence Ser Jeffory to death, and grant his lands to this uncle. We need someone to carry out the sentence, but I don't want a long, drawn out, siege. Sneak into Ser Jefforys keep and put an end to him and his scheming.
Very well, I will execute Ser Jeffory on behalf of King Joffrey.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes?
The uncle, I assume?
I am Ser Rike Darke, yes, the uncle of Ser Jeffory.

The king appreciates your help in putting an end to your nephews plotting, Ser Rike, and congratulates you on your ascension to master of Brookwater Keep. What a fortuitous circumstance, that you might serve your king, and gain a proper reward. Ser Jefforys father and grandfather might be proud.
Yes, well...
Hmph!
Yes, {playername}?
Lord Tyrion, I've taken care of Ser Jeffory.

Truly? Well done, {playername}. I'll make sure Bronn spreads the proper rumors about his demise. Should keep the rest of the lords in line. How did the uncle take it? Slimy worm, isn't he? Here, have this. One of my men found it in the castle cellar, supposively it belonged to Aemond the One-Eyed. It's old and worn, as you might expect of something that had a valyrian sword through it, and was then submerged in water for ten years, but it does have quite a story surrounding it.
Thank you, my lord.
May I know more about you, my lord?
I am Tyrion Lannister, Hand of the King.
Zapomeň na to.
Praise the Lord! The one that comes with shadows and fire!
Excuse me?
Hah, yes, excuses! Go see the laquered lady! She's back soon, she's always back!
Red lady, red lady, red lady, shadow lady!
{playername}.
How do you know my name?
Farewell.
I saw it in the fires.
What would you have me do?
Find the answers.
Erh...
Farewell.
Go north. Visit the fort of shadows. The Nightfort.
Very well...
I am not interested.
Yes?
{playername}.
How do you know my name? Who are you?
Farewell.
I saw your birth, and heard the name your mother bestowed upon you while you lay at her breast. I'm watching everything, and everyone, with a thousand eyes and one.
How?
The trees see all, and time is of no importance to them. The weirwoods hold many memories. My presence here is their memory.
But how? I don't understand.
Farewell.
The weirwoods will show you. Eat this paste, and you'll see.
Very well...
I am not interested.
Yes?
Taste this pie! It's filled with gravy, onions, bacon and prince!
It's filled with prince?
Tasty prince! The king wronged me, and now he'll pay! HE WILL PAY! The voices told me! They told me that the king was jesting about my knives! The voices... they have cold, blue, eyes...
Tasty prince, tasty bacon, crazy king! Where's my children?!
Arh! The cold hurts! He's bound us!
Who has bound you? What are you talking about?
HE bound us. With cold and blood, he's bound us to his will!
Kill me! Please kill me!
Yes?
Do you know of anyone who might have any tasks for me?
My uncle, Ser Gilbert, is looking for someone to do some... un-knightly work. He was here a minute ago, perhaps if you return later you can find him.
Praise the Lord of Light.
Yes? Can I help you?
Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.
Ah yes, I do, I do. But you have to keep silent about this.
What would you have me do?

Before the Old King abolished the lords right to the first night, the Targaryens where known to visit the smallfolk of Dragonstone to take their due, and they continued to do so even after the right was abolished. The resulting offspring was known as 'dragonseeds'. The dragonseeds used to be plenty on Dragonstone, but their numbers have dwindled over the years. However, recently a young man has been claiming to be the bastard son of Prince Rhaegar.
Hmm... go on.
Farewell.

This young man, going by the name of Lacerys, has been meeting with some of the knights from Hull, known to be descended from the Velaryons, and thus being akin to the dragonseeds. According to one of my informers, a man named Burlow, they've been talking of sneaking into the castle and overwhelming the guard, take the king hostage, and proclaim this Lacerys the true king of the Seven Kingdoms. This cannot be allowed to happen. I need you, {playername}, to break up the conspirators and execute the lot of them. They meet mostly at night, or when the fog rolls in from Dragonmont, obscuring the streets. We don't want to cause a scene, so just kill them and leave the bodies to be found.
Very well, I will execute these conspirators.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes?
Burlow, I assume?
Indeed I am, {playername}. Ser Gilbert told me you'd be coming.
What do you think, Burlow? Was Lacerys the son of Rhaegar?

Hah, that prancing fool? Not a chance. Plenty of silver-haired young men here on Dragonstone, the Targaryens had years to plant plenty of seeds. You'd be hard pressed to find someone without a bit of dragonblood on this island.
Hmph!
Yes, {playername}?
Ser Gilbert, I've taken care of the conspirators.

Truly? Well done, {playername}! His Grace, the king, has given me permission to choose a suitable reward from the armory in The Stone Drum. One of the weapons was rather fascinating. Taken from a Braavosi smuggler some years ago, it appears to be one of their slender blades, but forged for two hands rather than one. I imagine it would prove a rather poor cutting weapon, but it might prove to be exceptionally lethal as a stabbing tool. And of course, a monetary reward is due!
Thank you, Ser Gilbert.
Zapomeň na to.
Can you tell me more about the dragonseeds?
I don't know much more than the next man. Perhaps you could go talk to Archmaester Perestan in Oldtown, he's devoted much of his life to the history of Westeros.
Yes?
Do you know of anyone who might have any tasks for me?

I did hear a rumor a few days ago... Phario Forel, the playwright, is looking for someone to search some old tomb... he'll probably be here in a couple of hours, for some reason he's infatuated with Merry...
Yes?
Yes? Can I help you?
Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.
'The Father reached his hand into the heavens and pulled down seven stars and one by one he set them on the brow of Hugor of the Hill to make a glowing crown'...
Erh?
It's from the Seven-Pointed Star you ignorant savage! Bunch of Westerosi nonsense, but they did get the crown part right. Of course, it's not made by a god...
Hmm... go on.
Farewell.

The Andals wrought many fine treasures out of gold and copper. I have every reason to believe one of them might be buried in an old barrow, close to the Ruins of Iksa Calo. I need Andals treasures for my next play! The barrow is supposed to be haunted by wights and the ghosts of the Andal kings, but it's obviously just the wild rumours of madmen.
Very well, I will search for your Andal treasues.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes, {playername}?
I didn't find any Andal treasures.
Truly? Oh the curse of the sea upon that old fool! The Third Sword swore that I'd find what I seek in that barrow!
Well...
Can you tell me more about the Seven-Pointed Star?
Read it yourself!
Nevermind.
Erh, yes?
My lady, may I know more about you?
No... but perhaps you can acquire my favor by helping out a dear friend. Find Moredo Tendyris and talk to him. He's probably in the tavern, he has a weakness for music.
Go away.
Yes?
Lady Mellario said you where looking for help?
Ah yes! Caravans have been disapperaing in the Pass of Hugor Hill. I suspect a band of outlaws might be using one of the caves as a hideout.
What do you want me to do?
Go and search for the cave, and kill any outlaws you find
Hmm... go on.
Farewell.
You'll need to deal with the outlaws yourself, you'll never be able to surprise them by lumbering around with half an army.
Very well, I will take care of the outlaws.
I am not interested.
Farewell.
Yes?
Yes, {playername}?
I took care of the outlaws.
Well done {playername}! A reward is in order!
My thanks.
Can you tell me more about the Pass of Hugor Hill?
Nothing to tell, really. The pass got its name from Hugor Hill, obviously. Everything in the highlands is named after some Andal religious figure.
Zapomeň na to.
Yes, {playername}?
Did you have any more tasks for me?
Farewell.

Ah yes, I do. A close friend of mine has gone missing. He was visiting some ruined baths, north of Myr, but neither I, nor my associates, have heard from him since he set out weeks ago. He was supposed to be back by now. Foolish thing to visit baths, especially ruined ones, but there you are.
What would you have me do?
Go look for him. If he has met with an unfortunate end, I need you to return any books or scrolls he might carry, but I pray that is not the case. But find out what happened to him, {playername}!
Hmm...
Farewell.
I'll make sure you're well rewarded!
Very well, I will find this friend of yours.
I am not interested.
Yes?
Yes?
Hmph!
Are you Illyrios acquaintance?

Indeed I am, {playername}. My name is Haldon, and I appreciate the help. I've been looking for... nevermind. Anyhow, I ran into these bandits and they had me at their mercy when you came to my rescue.
Glad I could be of help.
I'm sure the magister will reward you handsomely for your work, {playername}. You seem an able fellow, and he might have... work for you, so visit him regularly.
Yes, {playername}?
I found Haldon and rescued him from a band of bandits.
Well done, {playername}! I think a reward is in order!
Thank you.
Who is Haldon?
Oh, just an old friend of mine. We call him 'Halfmaester' on account of him being almost a maester, but not quite.
Zapomeň na to.
What are you doing here? This is the private estate of Magister Mopatis!
Who is this magister?

He's one of the magisters of Pentos, you dolt! He should be back soon, and when he's back, he'll make you regret this trespassing! But if you have urgent business with him, you can find him at the court in Pentos.
Get out of here!
Welcome, my friend. I see you just barged in, without an invitation, but welcome nonetheless. What are you doing here, if you don't mind me asking?
I am {playername}, and I've come seeking adventure. Do you have any tasks for me?
Farewell.

Yes, {playername}, I do, I do. I need someone to brave the Smoking Sea, and set sail for far away Meereen. An... acquaintance of mine has taken up residence in the city, and I would dearly like to keep in contact with her, and thus I need someone to deliver this letter. So what do you say, {playername}, are you man enough for such a journey?
I will brave this Smoking Sea and sail to Meereen!
I'm afraid I can't carry that right now.

Splendid! You'll be well rewarded, I can assure you that. Once you reach Meereen, seek out Belandra Kheranes, she'll help you on your way. And just between us, if you where to bring some of your own coin with you on the journey, you might be able to make an excellent profit bringing back some spice. Now, sadly, my own ships are all away at sea, so you'll need to find your own way to Meereen.
Where can I find a ship?
On second thought, I think I'll stay on land.
Travel to Volantis, and you may be able to hire a ship there. Visit the tavern and see if you can't find Bayle Neres. He's an old rogue, not averse to travelling past Valyria. For the right price.
Very well, I'll return once I've seen Meereen.
I am not interested.
Yes?
I'm busy, away with you!
Are you Belandra Kheranes?
Yes, what's it to you?
My name is {playername}. Illyrio Mopatis sent me to seek out a friend of his and deliver this letter. I was told you could help me get in contact with this person?
Ah yes, {playername}, I can. The one you're looking for is named Barristan Selmy. If you head to the throne room, I'll make sure he'll meet you there.
What if I he's not there?
What if, what if. Don't worry, {playername}, he will be.
Hmph!
Yes?
Barristan Selmy? I've been sent with a letter.
Magister Illyrio has been a steadfast friend of the queens cause. I thank you for bringing me this, {playername}. Did you bring any additional messages from him?
No, he simply tasked me with making sure you received this letter, but he also asks that you keep him informed of your intentions.

Very well, {playername}. I'll have Missandei see to it that Magister Illyrio is kept aware of our intentions. Perhaps you should speak to Skahaz mo Kandaq, if you want to continue serving our cause, he may well have tasks for you.
Thank you.
Nevermind.
Yes?
Skahaz mo Kandaq? Ser Barristan told me you might have tasks for me?
Looking for work then? I believe I have a task for you, if you're man enough to handle it. Few are, but that's the general condition of people these days. Fret not, Meereen will be made great again.
Very wel.

My family has many dealings with the Free Cities. Her grace has, in her wisdom, outlawed slavery, and it's imperative that we find new ways to keep our markets full. To that effect, I've decided to send one of my own merchant vessels toward Tyrosh, that we might establish some small link with the trade of the Narrow Sea. But first the ship has to traverse the Stepstones, a notorious haunt of pirates. The lyseni cleared the islands a year ago, so the pirates have not yet been able to recover their strenght, but on the island of Bloodstone, there's an inkling of a new stronghold. I need you to go there and dispatch the pirates making it their home.
I'll clear out these pirates.
Dobrá tedy, bylo mi potěšením, {playername}.
Nothing, I'm leaving.
What do you want?
I'm looking for the pirates who have recently made Bloodstone their home.

They ain't here right now, they all went to the south of the island. Was going to prey on some myrish galley they said. Can't be a big galley, there's only eight of them, hah. What's it to you anyhow?
None of your concern!
Alright, alright, no harm done.
Guardsman. I'm just guarding this here gate.
Nothing.
Yes, {playername}
I've returned from the east.

Wonderful, {playername}! Did you find Ser Barristan? Is he well? Here, take this gift as my way of thanking you! Perhaps you'll be wanting to make use of it once the queen claims her rightful throne, eh?
Thank you, magister.

It's nothing, nothing! Say, should you wish to earn riches beyond your wildest dreams, then return to me in a couple of hours, I might have more work for you. There's always more work to be done, and little time. Men and events are converging, and soon all will change.
Do you have a need for sellswords? {reg3?Me and {reg4?{reg3} of my mates:one of my mates} are:I am} looking for a master. We'll join you for {reg5} silver coins.
Any orders?
Make your preparations. We'll be moving at dawn.
Take your time. We'll be staying in this town for a while.
Yes {Ser/my lady}. We'll be ready when you tell us to leave.
All right. I will hire all of you. Here is {reg5} silver coins.
All right. But I can only hire {reg6} of you. Here is {reg5} silver coins.
That sounds good. But I can't afford to hire any more {reg65?soldiers:men} right now.
That's a pity. Well, {reg3?we will:I will} be lingering around here for a while, if you need to hire anyone.
That sounds good. But I can't lead any more {reg65?soldiers:men} right now.
Sorry. I don't need any other men right now.

Good day to you {lad/lass}. You look like another adventurer who has come to try {his/her} chance in these lands. Well, trust my word, you won't be able to survive long here unless you know how to fight yourself out of a tight spot.
Díky za tvou radu. Tohle místo vypadá jako cvičiště. Možná bych se tu mohl něco přiučit?

To rozhodně ano. Jsem zkušený bojovník... bojoval jsem v mnoha bitvách za svých časů. Dnes však už jen cvičím mladé z okolí. Můžu ti najít pár soupeřů, se kterými můžeš cvičit, pokud chceš. Nebo pokud máš nějaké otázky ohledně teorie, tak se ptej.
Ano, pár otázek mám.
Myslím, že si zkusím ten souboj.
No, ptej se na co chceš.
Dobře. Je dobré najít si pár horlivců pro trénink. Uvidíme co dokážeš.
To byl dobrý boj.
Ha! Vypadá to, že ses nechal trochu omlátit. Ale i prohra má svou cenu. pokud se z ní poučíš. Trochu se oklep a vrať se zpátky na cvičiště. Není lepší způsob jak se to naučit.
Dobrý den, {připraven/připravena} pro nějaký ten trénink?
Ah, jsi {připraven/připravena} pro nějaké ten trénink?
Jsem {připraven/připravena}.
Nejprve mi něco pozvěz o soubojích...
Už musím odejít. Na viděnou.
Co chceš vědět?
Co dalšího chceš vědět?
Vyvětli mi jak se mám bránit.
Vysvětli mi jak provádět výpady.
Řekni mi něco o jezdeckých soubojích.
Myslím, že už znám vše co potřebuji.

Dobrá otázka. První věc, kterou musíš jako bojovník znát, je jak se bránit. Vyhnout se zranění je to nejdůležitější a mnohem důležitější, než umět dobře rány rozdávat. Každý může kolem sebe mávat mečem a doufat, že někoho zraní, ale jen ti, kteří jsou dobří v obraně přežijí, aby mohli o svých soubojích vyprávět.

Za prvé, obrana je nejjednodušší pokud se sebou máš štít. Stačí se jím pouze zakrýt. [Podrž pravé tlačítko myši pro obranu štítem.] Takto budeš {chráněn/chráněna} proti všem útoku zpředu, ale stále budeš {zranitelný/zranitelná} proti výpadům ze strana a do zad.
A co když se sebou žádný štít nemám?

Pak musíš použít svou zbraň k obraně. To je trochu náročnější, než krýt se štítem. Zbraní se můžeš bránit útoku pouze z jednoho směru. To znamená proti švihu shora, ze stran nebo proti bodnutí. Proto musíš svého soupeře pozorně sledovat a reagovat včas na jeho útok. Tak se ubráníš proti jeho výpadu. Pokud však budeš příliš spěchat a bránit se dřív než zaútočí, může si soupeř jednoduše zvolit jiný směr útoku, proti kterému budeš v tu chvíli {bezbranný/bezbranná}.

Dobrá otázka. Nakonec se říká, že útok je nejlepší obranou. Mnoho bojovníků se staví do útočného postavení a pak jen čeká na vhodnou příležitost k výpadu. [Svou zbraň můžeš připravit k útoku podržením levého tlačítka.]
To zní dobře.

To ano, ale má to i své nevýhody. Soupeř uvidí tvůj postoj a bude připraven se bránit tvému výpadu. V tom případě musíš svůj postoj co nejrychleji změnit a zaútočit odjinud. [Svůj postoj můžeš rychle přerušit stisknutím pravého tlačítka.]
Takže, když se nepřítel brání pro útoku ve směru v jakém ho vedu, musím ho rychle přerušit a zaútočit z jiné strany.

Přesně, výběr směrů útoku je jednou ze základních schopností dobrého bojovníka. Jsou zde čtyři hlavní směry útoku, které můžeš použít: pravý švih, levý švih, horní švih a bodnutí. Musíš každý z nich dobře využít. [Pro určení směrů útoku v základním nastavení pohni myší ve směru, z jakého chceš zaútočit, ve chvíli kdy stiskneš levé tlačítko.]

Velmi dobrá otázka. Kůň může být tvou nejlepší zbraní. Dává ti rychlost, výšku, sílu a iniciativu. mnoho smrtících zbraní se při použití na koni stává ještě smrtícími. Musíš si však dávat velký pozor na nepřátelské jezdce s kopím, protože tě mohou zabít v jediném okamžiku. [Pro použití kopí v sedle si vezmi kopí, nebo podobnou zbraň a bez stisknutí tlačítka pro útok, nebo obranu naber dostatečnou rychlost. Až dosáhneš nezbytné rychlosti, povolíš své kopí dopředu. Pak musíš trefit svého soupeře vedením svého koně.]
Trénuji své učně ve čtyřech fázích, každá náročnější, než ta předchozí. Abys splnil danou fázi, musíš vyhrát tři souboje v řadě.
{Splnil/Splnila} jsi vše co jsem ti zadal. Ale pokud chceš pokračovat v tréninku tak samozřejmě můžeš. Jsi {připravený/připravená}

Je čas se pohnout {chlapče/děvče}. S tímhle vítězstvím si {postoupil/postoupila} do další části. Od teď budeš bojovat se skutečnými protivníky, ne jen s nějakými chudáky z ulic, takže buď {opatrný/opatrná}.

Way to go {lad/lass}. Welcome to the third training level. From now on your opponents will be veteran fighters; soldiers and arena regulars and the like. These guys know some dirty tricks, so keep your defense up.

You've got the heart of a champion, {lad/lass}, and the sword arm to match. From now on your opponents will be champion fighters. These are the cream of the crop, the finest warriors I have trained. If you can best three of them in a row, you will join their ranks.
It does my heart good to see such a promising talent. You have passed all tiers of training. You can now tell everyone that you have been trained by the master of the training field.
Thank you master.
I wish you good luck in the tourneys. And, don't forget,  if you want to practice your swordwork anytime, just come and say the word.
Your next opponent will be a {s9}. You need to win {reg8} more fights in a row to advance to the next stage. Are you ready?
Yes I am.
Here you go then. Good luck.
Just a minute. I am not ready yet.
Hey, You will never make it if you don't practice.
Peace of the Father to you. I am a septon, a servant of the Seven.
The Warrior guard you, {playername}. What can his humble servant do for you?
The gods are nothing to me. How can you call them good, when they let us toil in this miserable world?
You... You... You're a demon, {playername}. Every righteous man in the Seven Kingdoms will stand against you.
I am but a sinner, septon, and I need your help.
I do not follow the Seven, but I would dearly like to learn more about the Faith.
I have other matters to attend to.

Oh, well. I pray for you {playername}, for the Father to forgive your sins.If it is your wish, I can pray for you and any men sworn to you, and have my congregation join me, that the Warrior may better hear us. But the Warrior will surely hear you better where you to make a small donation to the Faith.Or if you wish to improve your reputation in this town, to be known as a pious and just man, you might make a large donation to the local sept. The populace of {s60} will surely praise your name.
Thank you. I have sinned and the Father must forgive me - I will donate 300 coins.
Thank you, septon. I want the population of {s60} to love me. I will donate 2000 coins.
Are you selling forgiveness?
Vlastně, zapomeň na to.
Peace of the Father to you. I am the High Septon, and I speak for the Seven themselves.
The Mother bless you, {playername}. What can I do for you?
Your gods are cruel. The gods responsible for all this misery will never have my worship.
You speak out of ignorance, {playername}. If you do not turn from your path of wickedness, your soul will be forever condemned.
I am but a sinner, Your Holiness, and I need your forgiveness.
I do not follow the Faith, but I would like to learn of its mysteries.
I have other matters to attend to.

I will pray for you {playername}, so the Father might forgive your sins and the Mother grant you peace. If it is your wish, I can order the septs in King's Landing to pray for you and any men sworn to you, and even have the court join me, that the Father may better hear us. But he will surely hear you better where you to make a small donation to the Faith.Or if you wish to improve your reputation in this land, to be known as a pious and just man, you might make a large donation to the Great Sept of Baelor. The populace of {s60} will surely praise your name, and word of your great generosity will spread to the countryside.
Thank you. I have sinned and the Father must forgive me - I will donate 5000 coins.
Thank you, high septon. I want the population of {s60} to love me. I will donate 10000 coins.
Are you selling forgiveness?
Vlastně, zapomeň na to.
I am a servant of the Drowned God.
What is dead may never die, but rises again, harder and stronger.
The gods are nothing to me. How can you call them good, when they let us toil in this miserable world?
The Drowned God cares not for your doubts, and neither do I.
What is dead may never die, but rises again, harder and stronger.
I have not been drowned in the waters of He Who Dwells Beneath the Waves, but perhaps you can teach me of his ways.
I have other matters to attend to.

The Drowned God may hear your prayers if the Drowned Men chant your name close to the sea. If it is your wish, I can make it so. But be warned, the Drowned God is not one of those soft green gods from across the water. If you wish to improve your reputation with the ironborn, to be known as a devout and righteous man, let me drown you in the waters.
Thank you. Let the name of {playername} be heard echoing in the watery halls beneath the waves.
Yes. Let me be drowned in the waves, that I might rise, harder and stronger..
Vlastně, zapomeň na to.
I am Aeron Greyjoy, a servant of the Drowned God.
The Drowned God is the only god. The gods of the green lands are nothing but myths and foolish stories.
The gods are nothing to me. How can you call them good, when they let us toil in this miserable world?
You're a godless man. Your doubt will be punished when the Drowned God sees fit to throw you down.
What is dead may never die, but rises, harder and stronger.
I have not been drowned in the waters of He Who Dwells Beneath the Waves, but perhaps you can teach me of his ways.
I have other matters to attend to.
